newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains fed cattle thin at $68 late - feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains fed cattle thin at $68 late - feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle markets were at a standstill for most of Tuesday, with extremely light sales reported late at $68.00 per cwt, feedlot sources said.
One pen, or about 200 heifers, that will likely grade select and choice sold at $68.00 in the Texas Panhandle, steady with last week, USDA said. There were no sales reported in Kansas.
Packer buyers and cattle owners were at a stalemate most of the day, with bids at $65.00-$66.00 passed by owners pricing cattle at $69.00-$70.00, the feedlot sources said.
Prices were expected to be underpinned by expectations that packers would be in the market Wednesday or Thursday to refresh live cattle inventories, they said.

The demand for cattle was expected to offset possible pressure from increased showlist supplies this week, cattle sources said. The lists were expanded by a carryover of unsold cattle from last week, sources said.

Support in fed cattle prices could be limited, however, if beef values continue to weaken. Heavyweight choice beef at midday was quoted at $104.92, down $1.05 per cwt from Monday and down $2.87 from last Tuesday, USDA statistics showed.
